LAST PERSON RURAL Essays. By Noel Perrin. Godine, $21.95.

Noel Perrin shows us that country living is a lot of hard work. But the result, for him at least, is pure bliss. In "Last Person Rural," Mr. Perrin writes of the joys of owning a power winch and heating with wood. He discusses mulch, ponds and farm equipment. He reviews books on gardening, forestry and farmers. He provides an address where one can obtain good (and cheap) Vermont maple syrup. And he rhapsodizes about walking across a meadow at dawn with his daughter. As can be expected, Mr. Perrin exhibits a certain disdain for the benefits of technology in his essays on agribusiness and acid rain. The author, a professor of environmental studies at Dartmouth College, advocates a return to organic farming and urges readers to pay more for natural foods as a way of discouraging farmers' reliance on chemicals to increase yields. Mr. Perrin's prose is straightforward, flinty, spare, dry and ironic, and he celebrates his little corner of New England with eloquent simplicity.
